repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This hopefully "finishes" the support for unicode identifiers. It builds off https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3096, so I don't think there's much point in looking at it before that's finalized.

It adds ~~2 features~~ 1 feature:
1. ~~Support for unicode identifiers in C/C++ features such as structs and cppclasses. For structs used purely in Python I've mangled the names with punycode. For features that are exported/imported to C with "public" or "extern", I've translated the names to be \uXXXX escaped (without any mangling or normalization). Pretty much every modern C/C++ compiler supports unicode in identifiers in this form (only Clang supports it in raw form I think), so this this seems like the most compatible thing to do. I've trusted that the user knows what names they want and not performed any normalization for these (I don't think normalization is yet defined in C/C++ standards, so it's hard to do anything else).~~

2. Support for import of modules with unicode in their names. As in PEP 489 this is only supported from Python 3.5 onwards (but the Cython translation step should work fine in earlier versions...). The Python 2 filename handling in Cython.Build seems a bit fragile with unicode filenames (since most os.path functions require bytes) - I haven't made any serious attempt to fix that beyond getting my test-cases to work.

comment_data.body: `encode_filename_in_py2()` is designed to be "just callable", no need for prior type/version checks.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

     for pattern in patterns:
+        if sys.version_info[0]==2 and isinstance(pattern, unicode):
+            pattern = encode_filename_in_py2(pattern)

comment_data.body: I'd say, at least one blank line after this function, if you want to keep the link to the usage below.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,8 +32,21 @@
 from . import Options
 from .Options import CompilationOptions, default_options
 from .CmdLine import parse_command_line
+from .Lexicon import (unicode_start_ch_any, unicode_continuation_ch_any,
+                      unicode_start_ch_range, unicode_continuation_ch_range)
+
+def _make_range_re(chrs):
+    out = []
+    for i in range(0, len(chrs), 2):
+        out.append(u"{0}-{1}".format(chrs[i], chrs[i+1]))
+    return u"".join(out)
+# py2 version looked like r"[A-Za-z_][A-Za-z0-9_]*(\.[A-Za-z_][A-Za-z0-9_]*)*$"

comment_data.body: The module name could probably also just always be a unicode string, but if you want to keep this as version specific handling here, then please make it at least visible from the code that it is version specific by checking the version.

comment_data.body:
This is generating Cython code so I believe it's correct to use the name, rather than the cname (although the vast majority of the time they're the same). Here's a non-unicode example of something that works now but didn't before:

```
cdef struct S:
    int x "not_x"
def f(d):
    """
    >>> f({ 'x': 1 })
    1
    """
    cdef S s = d
    print(s.x)
```

Although really this is related to the struct support (which is getting moved out of this PR) I'm going to leave this bit in because it fixes existing bugs.

-    result.{{member.cname}} = value
+    result.{{member.name}} = value

comment_data.body: I did have a look at changing filenames and module to unicode names earlier. Seemed to involve rewriting nearly all the code that handles resolving cimport paths, so in the end I decided to do it here. I agree that it ideally should be done earlier, but it actually doing it was turning out to be too nasty. I'll make the version-specific bit clearer though

comment_data.body:
It needs `as_c_string_literal` to avoid putting unicode characters in the C source. `replace` returns a plain `unicode` object rather than an `EncodedString` even if the input is an `EncodedString` so it does need converting.

It does pass the testsuite in Python2 (the majority of which is plain ASCII filenames) so I think it isn't a real issue.

I've changed it slightly to be either an EncodedString or a ByteString depending on what type escaped_filename is

-                code.putln('"%s",' % escaped_filename)
+                code.putln('%s,' % EncodedString(escaped_filename).as_c_string_literal())

comment_data.body: It's now changed to be slightly different. I was trying not to change the api names generated for existing non-unicode modules. The version I've changed it to generated `import_name` for non-unicode names (as before) and `importU_punycodename` for unicode modules, which I think is reasonable. It's essentially because punycode_module_name returns something starting with "_"

comment_data.body:
What is `x` here?
I think it's generally not a good idea to reuse the name of an imported function and then let it do something else. This function apparently does something specific to file names. That should be reflected in its name.

comment_data.body: What about adding a `name_is_ascii()` helper function to `Utils.py` that try-encodes in Py2 and just calls `isascii()` in Py3? That would avoid all these repeated `try-except` usages.

comment_data.body: I would allow a `prefix` argument here and pass it through. That makes the concatenation more obvious.
The `full_module_name` should just always be an `EncodedString`, created in `Parsing.p_module()`. I think that's the only place where we create a `ModuleNode` and set the attribute.

+        code.putln('#define __Pyx_MODULE_NAME %s' %
+                   EncodedString(self.full_module_name).as_c_string_literal())

@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
+# tag: py3, pep489
+
+PYTHON setup.py build_ext --inplace
+PYTHON -m mydoctest
+
+########### mydoctest.py #######
+
+import sys
+if (sys.version_info[0] < 3 or
+    (sys.version_info[0] == 3 and sys.version_info[1] < 5)):
+    # The module is only Cythonized and not build for these versions
+    # so don't run the tests
+    exit()
+    
+import doctest
+import from_py
+val = doctest.testmod(from_py)[0]
+import from_cy
+val += doctest.testmod(from_cy)[0]
+
+exit(val)
+
+########### setup.py ########
+
+# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
+
+from __future__ import unicode_literals
+
+import sys
+from Cython.Build import cythonize
+
+files = ["mymoδ.pyx", "from_cy.pyx"]
+
+
+# For Python 2 and Python <= 3.4 just run pyx->c; 
+# don't compile the C file
+modules = cythonize(files)

commit.message:
Handle normalization of unicode identifiers

Also add a test-case. (Also add a test case for passing keyword
arguments, which already worked, but is good to have as a test
case).

Allow unicode named structs/other C items

When they are to be used internally the name is mangled with
punycode as normal. When they are to be used externally
(e.g. "cdef public" or "cdef from extern") the name is taken
exactly as-is and simply slash-escaped ("\uNNNN"). The
vast majority of C compilers are capable to dealing with
\uNNNN characters in literal names.

Support unicode characters in module names

(Only valid under Python 3)

Unicode structs -> dict

Added tests and a small fix

Fixed breakage of single-phase init

+ a few other small errors in generation of module code
Fixed broken building using Extension on Python2

Revert "Allow unicode named structs/other C items"

This reverts commit 463c7f9a537c8808eb707e80bb696c5bef9647c1.
Removes the more controversal unicode C identifiers, but leaves
unicode modules

Made requested changes from code review

Also, handle generated .h files properly

title: unicode imports
